data.title: Non-relative imports lose type definitions
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. import a module with a full path, ie `import A from 'app/models/a';`
2. Type definition for A is lost, and the intellisense with it

Note that when I change this import path to be relative from my current location, it works perfectly.  Also, this is completely unrelated to my prior issue https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24702 since I'm only using .js files here.

Possibly related, but is there a way to tell VS Code what the "root" for all non-relative import statements is?  In other words, all of our code is inside a `src` folder. Can I tell VS Code that the root for all non-relative imports is from `src`?

To be clear, I *did* try adding both `src/` and `/src/` to my import path, but neither worked.

data.title: Unable to get type definitions on imports with non .js extension
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Import some class with `import X from './x'`
2. VS Code is not able to detect the type, and therefore provide intellisense.

We're on a manual transpilation watch task, which listens for changes to .es6 files, and spits out transpiled .js files right next to the originals. So my class is in x.es6 - I assume VS Code is looking in the neighboring x.js which just has CJS?  How can I tell VS Code to always look in .es6 files?

To be clear, if I change the x.es6 file in this example to be x.js, then it works perfectly and beautifully, so I have definitely narrowed it down to the file extension.

My current user settings looks like this

```
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{
    "files.exclude": {
        "**/.gitignore": true,
        "**/.git": true,
        "**/.svn": true,
        "**/.hg": true,
        "**/.DS_Store": true,
        "**/*.js":{ "when": "$(basename).es6" },
        "**/*.es6":{ "when": "$(basename).jsx" }
    },
    "explorer.openEditors.visible": 0,
    "files.associations": {
        "*.js": "javascriptreact",
        "*.es6": "javascriptreact"   
    },
    "javascript.validate.enable": false,
    "window.zoomLevel": 0,
    "html.suggest.angular1": false,
    "html.suggest.ionic": false,
    "git.enabled": false
}
```

data.title: TypeScript server crashes faster than ever
data.body:
sorry, rant

Never famous for its stability `tsserver` has come to a new high of crashing every 2 minutes. To reproduce, open our source and navigate across some files. Find log files and output attached

```
[Info  - 5:30:05 PM] Using tsserver from location: /Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js
[Error - 5:31:44 PM] TSServer exited with code: unknown
[Info  - 5:31:44 PM] Using tsserver from location: /Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js
```

data.title: [Feature request] GIT: group changes by status
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12 insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 Creators Update

When viewing source control changes, it would be great if it was possible to:

 - group files by status (ie: untracked or modified files)
 - have a checkbox that allows to toggle viewing untracked files

Sometimes you created lots of files but just want to commit one or two files. Since all files are listed (no matter if they are untracked or modified), it makes it difficult to pick the ones you want to stage:

![vscodegit](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/25012166/f4860070-206f-11e7-93d2-69d463393d5b.png)

data.title: TypeScript server log contains PII and source code
data.body:
* have a `tsserver.log` file and have the goal of filing an issue
* take a look at the file
* üêõ file is full of file paths and even source code

We should *clearly* warn about this before encouraging people to attach that file to an (public) issue.

data.title: Get rid of EditorInput objects or make them lightweight again

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
My understanding of `EditorInput` is that they are light and throwaway objects and are used to seed a heavy editor object. Even the [doc](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/common/editor.ts#L130) says

> Editor inputs are lightweight objects that can be passed to the workbench API to open inside the editor part.
  Each editor input is mapped to an editor that is capable of opening it through the Platform facade.

This contradicts the semantic change done via https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/176f3504540d9eeee43990243c9223c2c66b3465 which means input are now fat, emit events, and thereby have a lifecycle. Now there is a [lot of code to find a potential existing input and update it](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/html/browser/html.contribution.ts#L80), tho then still calling `open` which makes it even more weird. Is it a live object or not?

data.title: Spanish ISO keyboard layout: BUG / Keyboard shortcuts could be considered 'mislabeled' on foreign keyboard layouts
data.body:
# Regression / Bug

- VSCode Version:
Version 1.11.1 (1.11.1)
- OS Version:
macOS Sierra v 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Connect a foreign keyboard layout (in my case a Spanish ISO keyboard layout)
2. Try to toggle the line comments using `shift + cmd + &` and it won't work, but using `shift + cmd + /` works. 

I think there might be some confusion as the Spanish keyboard layouts have the `&` on the `6` key while US Keyboard style layouts have the `&` on the `7` key

data.title: Linux Mint: OS-level evdev key remap ignored, only in newer vscode versions
data.body:
I finally caved to vscode's nagging and upgraded it (from a version I had downloaded in February, IIRC, but I'm not sure the version number) only to find that my custom keybinding suddenly broke.  Since the key in question is the "end" key, this basically makes vscode unusable for me, which is really unfortunate, because I was really liking it so far.  I'm on Linux Mint 18.1 x64:

- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.1 (d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39, 2017-04-06T13:55:56.395Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-53-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-database|bajdzis|1.2.0|
|vshaxe|nadako|1.5.0|;

I have an external USB Mac keyboard plugged into my acer laptop.  Because the Mac keyboard has no End key, I remapped the keypad Enter to cover this functionality; it's conveniently placed, without being easy to make a typo on, and takes up a redundant key.

I did this with the following line:

```
	<END> = 104; // instead of 115, so my external Mac keyboard has an "end" button (the numpad Enter)
```

in `/usr/share/X11/xkb/keycodes/evdev`.

Everywhere else in the OS this still works, and it worked in vscode too, before the upgrade just now.

After the upgrade, I tried to fix things using vscode's "Keyboard Shortcuts" preflet, but when I try to map cursorEnd to the numpad enter key, it gets input as "enter".  After that, it works, but then my regular Enter key (above Shift) now also functions as cursorEnd, so I have no way of inserting linebreaks.

I hope the behaviour is reverted in future versions.

Thankfully I was able to downgrade by installing from here http://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode/pool/main/c/code/code_1.9.1-1486597190_amd64.deb and everything works again.

data.title: Git support for setting upstream/tracking branch
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1, commit d9484d12b
- OS Version: Windows Server 2008 R2 Datacenter

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new branch
2. Make local commits
3. <ctrl>+p git push to
4. Select remote
5. Make more local commits
6. <ctrl>+p git push

Second push fails because there is no upstream/tracking branch set. Must breakout to terminal and manually set upstream.

data.title: Please Add Search in files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: latest version
- OS Version: windows 10

Requesting a new feature. Please add search in files, so that the user can search for a particular string by giving the location of the file. this feature is currently having in notepad++ for reference.
